Rains likely to hit Andhra by June 18.description: AMARAVATI: In Andhra Pradesh, conditions for onset of monsoon are likely to be favourable over the next two to three days and is likely to hit the state only by June 18. “At present, an upper air cyclonic circulation is marked over West central Bay of Bengal off Andhra Pradesh Coast at mid and upper tropospheric level. Further, we expect this weather system to intensify more,” read a weather report issued by Skymet, an independent weather forecasting agency. “In the wake of all these weather systems, clouds will increase gradually and rain intensity will be spreading over to northern parts of Andhra Pradesh,” the weather report further stated. These weather activities will be accompanied by strong winds and are expected to continue for coming four to five days. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Doctors' strike hit healthcare services.description: HYDERABAD/AMARAVATI: The nationwide strike called by the Indian Medical Association (IMA) to protest the attack on doctors in West Bengal affected medical services in government and private hospitals in Telangana and Andhra Pradesh. The out-patient services at major government hospitals like Osmania General Hospital, Gandhi Hospital and Nizam's Institute of Medical Sciences (NIMS) in Hyderabad came to a standstill. Hundreds of patients who came to these hospitals from various parts of the state had to face hardships as doctors stayed away from their duties and participated in protests condemning attacks on their colleagues in West Bengal. Doctors boycotted all services except emergency at the government and corporate hospitals and nursing homes. Doctors at Osmania Hospital staged a protest, demanding punishment to those involved in the attack. They were carrying placards with slogans like 'no security no service' and 'suffering but still serving'. At the protest held at Gandhi Hospital, the doctors demanded stringent law to deal with the attacks on their fraternity. Out-patient services also came to a halt at government and private hospitals in the rest of Telangana. Patients suffered in Andhra Pradesh as doctors struck work in response to the shutdown call by the IMA. Doctors at hospitals in Vijayawada, Guntur, Visakhapatnam, Tirupati, Kurnool and other places boycotted their duties and staged protests. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

TDP MLC Keshav quits, 3 more to resign s.description: VIJAYAWADA: TDP MLC Payyavula Keshav resigned from his post in the legislative council on Tuesday. He submitted his resignation to the council chairman, Mohammad Ahmad Shariff, who accepted it with immediate effect. Keshav quit his MLC post following his election to the legislative assembly from Uravakonda constituency in Anantapur district. Another TDP MLC, Magunta Srinivasulu Reddy, had quit his post before joining the YSR Congress in March. With Keshav’s resignation, the assembly secretariat has officially declared two vacancies in the 58-member legislative council. Meanwhile, three sitting MLCs — two from the YSR Congress and one from the TDP — also contested the assembly elections and won. They are also expected to submit their resignations from the legislative council sometime this week, as the new assembly is likely to be convened for the swearing-in of members on June 12. The three MLCs who won the assembly elections include Kolagatla Veerabhadra Swamy from Vizianagaram and Alla Nani from Eluru (both YSR Congress), and Karanam Balaramakrishna Murthy from Chirala (TDP). Once the three quit, the legislative council will have five vacancies, for which elections will be held shortly. As Veerabhadra Swamy, Alla Nani and Karanam Balaram were elected to the council from MLA quota, the ruling YSR Congress, with a strength of 151 MLAs in the 175-member assembly, will grab the three posts without any problem. The other two — Payyavula Keshav and Magunta Srinivasula Reddy — were elected from local body constituencies of Anantapur and Prakasam districts, respectively. The two vacancies are to be filled by the local bodies and it is to be seen what happens next as the local bodies’ terms expired a couple of months ago and new bodies are yet to be formed. Lok Sabha Elections in Tamil Nadu.description: NEW DELHI: Tamil Nadu goes to polls in the second phase of the seven-phase elections. Elections to 39 parliamentary seats will take place on April 18 in a single-phase polling. Lok Sabha elections 2019: Get all live updatesTOP CONTENDERSThe four-cornered contest features AIADMK-led National Democratic Alliance (NDA), its chief rival DMK-led Secular Progressive Alliance (SPA), actor Kamal Haasan's Makkal Needhi Maiam and TTV Dhinakaran's Amma Makkal Munnetra Kazhagam (AMMK). This time the elections are taking place sans the Dravidian stalwarts M Karunanidhi and J Jayalalithaa. AIADMK chief Jayalalithaa passed away in December 2016 while Karunanidhi died in August 2018. While the DMK is contesting on 20 seats, the Congress is fighting elections on 9 seats in Tamil Nadu. In the AIADMK-BJP alliance, the national party will be contesting from five seats in the state while the PMK will be contesting from seven. Tamil Nadu Lok Sabha elections: Get all live updatesHOW MANY SEATS?Tamil Nadu has 39 Lok Sabha seats and one in neighbouring Puducherry. Here is the list of constituencies: Arakkonam, Arani, Chennai Central, Chennai North, Chennai South, Chidambaram(SC), Coimbatore, Cuddalore, Dharmapuri, Dindigul, Erode, Kallakurichi, Kancheepuram(SC), Kanyakumari, Karur, Krishnagiri, Madurai, Mayiladuthurai, Nagapattinam(SC), Namakkal Nilgiris(SC), Perambalur, Pollachi, Ramanathapuram, Salem, Sivaganga, Sriperumbudur, Tenkasi(SC), Thanjavur, Theni, Thiruvallur(SC), Thoothukudi, Tiruchirapalli, Tirunelveli, Tiruppur, Tiruvannamalai, Vellore, Villupuram(SC), Virudhunagar, Puducherry(Union Territory) KEY CONSTITUENCIESThe key constutuencies include Sivaganga, Chennai South, Chennai North, Chennai Central, Chidambaram(SC), Coimbatore, Cuddalore, Dharmapuri, Dindigul, Kanyakumari, Karur, Thoothukudi , Nilgiris(SC), Trichy, Vellore amd Arani.
